message.content: We refer to UpToDate article on management of abnormal cervical cancer screening test results. The patient has ASC-US on her Pap test, but a negative HPV test, which puts her at low risk for cervical cancer. The current guidelines recommend repeat cytology and HPV testing in 3 years for low-risk women with ASC-US and negative HPV test results. Colposcopy or excisional treatment is not indicated at this point.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ASC-US is an ambiguous result that warrants further evaluation with HPV testing. Since the reflex HPV test is negative, the patient can be managed with repeat cytology and HPV testing in 3 years, as recommended by the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP) guidelines. Excisional treatment is not indicated in this case. Colposcopy may be considered if repeat testing shows abnormal results, but it is not the recommended next step in this scenario.

We refer to the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP) guidelines for help. The patient has ASC-US on Pap test but negative reflex HPV test. The ASCCP recommends repeating cytology and HPV testing in 3 years for patients with ASC-US and negative HPV test results. Colposcopy is recommended for patients with ASC-US and positive HPV test results. Excisional treatment is not indicated for this patient.

We refer to the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology (ASCCP) guidelines for help. In cases where the patient has ASC-US and a negative HPV test, management includes repeat cytology and HPV testing in 3 years. Colposcopy or excisional treatment is not recommended in this scenario.

We refer to UpToDate articles on medicine for help. ASC-US is a borderline Pap smear result that requires further evaluation. A negative HPV test suggests low risk for high-grade lesions, so repeat cytology and HPV testing in 3 years is the best option. Colposcopy is recommended for women with persistent ASC-US or other concerning results on further testing. Excisional treatment is not indicated at this time.

We refer to UpToDate for help. The patient has ASC-US on her Pap test, which means that further evaluation is warranted. The negative HPV test suggests that the likelihood of significant cervical disease is low, and follow-up with repeat cytology and HPV testing in 3 years is appropriate. Colposcopy or excisional treatment is not necessary at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ASC-US is an abnormal result but not a definitive diagnosis for precancerous or cancerous cells. Since the reflex HPV test is negative, the risk for cervical dysplasia is lower, and the patient can be managed with observation and repeat cytology and HPV testing in 3 years. Colposcopy may be performed if the repeat test shows a persistent abnormality. Excisional treatment is not recommended without a definitive diagnosis of precancerous or cancerous cells.

We refer to the American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical Pathology guidelines for help. With ASC-US and negative HPV test, the recommended management is repeat cytology and HPV testing in 3 years. Colposcopy is not needed without further abnormal results. Excisional treatment is not recommended at this stage.

We refer to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists' guidelines for cervical cancer screening for help. ASC-US is an ambiguous finding on Pap test and requires further evaluation. However, a negative HPV test means the risk of developing cervical cancer is low. The best next step is to repeat cytology and HPV testing in 3 years. Colposcopy is indicated if the repeat cytology results are abnormal or if the HPV test becomes positive. Excisional treatment is not indicated for ASC-US.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. ASC-US warrants further evaluation but HPV testing is negative, so repeating cytology and HPV testing in 3 years is the most appropriate management. Colposcopy or excisional treatment are reserved for more severe findings. Routine screening every 3 years is only recommended for patients with normal results.
